div.p: 1. VI:15. Friday

Anthony Giusta came this morning and told me of his future projects— He has sold his bar-room establishment, and retires from it with ten thousand dollars, part of which he is anxious to invest— He will see me again on Sunday morning— One of his purposes is to visit his native Country of Piedmont— At the Capitol, I met the joint Committee upon the Paintings— Present Preston and Wall of the Senate, Jarvis, Adams, H. Johnson, and M’Keon of the House. Absent Wright of the Senate and Howard of the House— It was agreed, Wall and M’Keon dissenting that Allston should be engaged for two of the four Pictures; and that Vanderlyn, Weir, Inman, and Chapman should be written to by the two Chairmen, for sketches or designs for large pictures upon which the Committee may afterwards select— In the House after sundry common-place transactions—Dixon H. Lewis presented a Memorial from numerous inhabitants of parts of Alabama, calling for a Legislative investigation of land jobbing frauds which they alledge to be cause of the Indian War, with which they are desolated— It gave rise to a warm and sharp debate— Lewis first proposed to refer the memorial to the President— Wise moved as amendment reference to a select Committee—then to the Committee on Indian Affairs— Ripley moved reference to the President, which I strenuously opposed and had a keen dialogue with Mann of New-York who said that all Legislative investigations were humbugs— I spoke till the recess. In the evening, after much manoeuvering Ripley’s Amendment referring the whole subject was carried by a vote of 95 to 91. Wise and Peyton made long and very teizing Speeches. Private Bills were taken up about 9 in the Evening, and about half past one of the morning between 50 and 60 of them were carried through—less than 60 members being in the House. Jarvis rode home with me—
2 VI:30. Saturday

Mr Cutts called upon me this morning under an apprehension, that in the Bill giving the franking privilege to Mrs. Madison a mistake had been made in her name— But the mistake was only in the newspaper report and not in the Bill— I called at the Bank of the Metropolis, and received the Speakers check for 588 dollars in 1/2 Eagles and 6 half dollars— Settled Bills at P. Thompson’s and at Jacobs’s— At the House after some miscellaneous business Hiram P. Hunt from the select Committee appointed to investigate the land and bank speculations of Members of Congress made a report in part—much suspicion, but no proof—and above all no names mentioned— The Committee asked an increase of their numbers to nine—and leave to sit during the recess— Hunt made a short Speech, but a motion to lay the Report on the table was carried by a vote of 98 to 71. but the report was ordered to be printed— The House went into Committee of the whole John Y. Mason in the Chair— Jarvis called up the bill for erecting a Treasury Department building, the unfinished business of the Committee of the whole at the adjournment on Thursday— But the Chairman, said as no new Bill could be sent to the Senate on the last three days of the Session, that Bill had lost its place in the orders of the day— The Bill from the Senate for reorganizing the general Land-Office was taken up and debated till the recess.

The Evening was occupied much as usual on the last Night of a Session— A multitude of Bills were passed as fast as they could be muttered over by the Clerks— The Senate Bills were hurried through the Committee of the whole, engrossment and passage, with extreme impatience of the House at any proposal of amendment—the Treasury building Bill, the reorganization of the Land Office and Patent Office, and several other Bills which it had been impossible to get up separately were now crowded down as amendments to a supplementary general Appropriation Bill— I made a question upon a manifestly erroneous decision of John Y. Mason as chairman of the Committee of the whole, but was voted down unanimously.
2 and 3.— Saturday and Sunday—

The House continued in Session till 40 minutes past four of Sunday morning— About two O’Clock, Sutherland being Chairman of the Committee of the whole on the state of the Union, and a Bill to increase the number of the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States forced into Committee upon two successive counts by Tellers there was found no Quorum— H. Everett moved that the Committee should rise, and report the fact to the House; according to Parliamentary rule— But Sutherland persisted in attempting to count the members present; upon which Sherrod Williams of Kentucky said he called the chairman to order— Sutherland ordered him to take his Seat, which he refused and ordered the Chairman to take his Seat— Upon this loud to deafening cries of order rung through the Hall, and Williams in fury howled defiance to the Chairman and to the House.— Sutherland immediately sent for the Speaker, who took the Chair, and Sutherland reported the fact that Williams upon being called to order by him had set him at defiance, upon which he had of course left the Chair— Polk the Speaker, whimpered about the novelty, the delicacy and the difficulty of the case, and asked Sutherland to resume the Chair which he peremptorily refused unless Williams should apologize— After much negotiation with Williams to get an explanation from him; he persisting in his offence Pearce of Maryland offered a Resolution of direct censure upon Williams which passed by a vote almost unanimous— Sutherland then resumed the Chair—several Bills passed in Committee and through the House, which at 40 minutes past 4. adjourned till 8. O’Clock to-morrow Morning— Jarvis rode home with me by Sunshine— At 11. I attended at the Presbyterian Church, and heard Mr Blagden of Boston, from 2. Kings 5.12. “Are not Abana and Pharpar, rivers of Damascus, better than all the waters of Israel? may I not wash in them and be clean? So he turned and went away in a rage”— Mr Abbott Lawrence was at the Church
Mr and Mrs Frye and Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith and Thomas J. Frye dined with us— M. A. Giusta was here after dinner, and will come again on Tuesday.
4. V:30. Monday
Independence day.

The House met at 8 O’Clock. A.M. A large QuorumMembers present. I found the House in Session— Motions to suspend the 17th. joint Rule, that no Bill shall be sent to the President for his signature on the last day of the Session— There were four Bills which passed the House yesterday morning; after the Senate had adjourned— Suspension moved for those 4 Bills— Then Thomas moved to add three or four others, not finally acted upon by the House—among the rest the Bill for increasing the number of the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States. This gave rise to debate which continued till near Noon I asked twice for a division of the Question, which the Speaker decided against me, and the House sustained him He cited a Precedent of 1830. though a more recent decision of the House had reversed the decision to which he referred— The Senate however concurred only with the Resolution upon the Bills which had passed both Houses— John Y. Mason from the Committee of Foreign Relations made a Report on the Affairs of Texas, concluding with two Resolutions like those of the Senate— I moved to lay them on the Table; stating that I had many objections against them which there was now no time for me to detail. The house refused to lay the Resolutions on the Table— Balie Peyton moved the previous question upon the Resolutions and it was carried— I asked a division, and that the question was put upon each Resolution separately— They were carried by votes of 136 to 20 and 22. Cushing voting for them. The vote to censure Sherrod Williams was reconsidered and rejected upon his making a paltering explanation. Sutherland however declared himself satisfied— Soon after 2. O’Clock the Speaker adjourned the House to the first Monday in December I spent half an hour in the chamber of the Committee of Manufactures—near an hour in the Library, and came home worn out and exhausted about 4. P.M— In the afternoon, and Evening, I had a visit to take leave from Mr Southard, and one from Mr John Pope, who is to leave the City on his return to Kentucky to-morrow Morning— He was unwell.
5. V:30. Tuesday

Mr Patterson called this morning about his application for a patent. By the new Patent Law, the fee required for a Patent, from a British subject is 500 dollars— He said Mr Preston had told him the fees for Patents to foreigners would be much increased. Mr Jarvis called and shewed me the Letters to Allston, and to Vanderlyn, Weir Inman and Chapman, which the Chairman of the joint Committee on the Rotundo paintings have written. I rode out with the children; and called at Mr Phillips lodgings, and left the Texian Newspapers and Dr Channings pamphlet on Slavery which he had lent me— At Brown’s Hotel to see Mr John Pope, but he had left that house at two O’Clock this morning— At Gales and Seaton’s Office— Settled my bill there Conversation with Gales about Texas. He concurs with my opinions; but does not avow it in the National Intelligencer. At the Patent Office— Mr H. L. Ellsworth the Superintendent was at the President’s, re-organizing the Patent Department. I left the assignment ofPatents to be recorded, and then forwarded to me. At the Capitol, where I returned the Books I had taken out of the Congress Library—excep the Journals of the Senate and H.R.U.S. 19. Congress 1. Session, which I had given to be deposited at the Clerk’s table, and which could not now be found— I took the children to see the Rotundo; the library, and the Senate chamber— At the Prison where I saw William Otis— I had given directions at the Clerk’s Office of the House, that his papers should be sent to him— He told me he hoped to make some adjustment of his claims with the Executive Department— Visits from Major Thomas, Mrs Frye, W. S. Smith, Mrs Tudor, Mrs Stuart and her Son Charles T—and M. A. Giusta was here, and left a Picture with an internal organ, which at the touch of a string played two Musical airs; one of which was the Ranz des vaches— Thunder shower this Evening after a midsummer Washington day— Began the packing of Trunks for departure
6. V: Wednesday— From Washington to Baltimore

Occupied all the morning in settling Bills and accounts— At the Bank of the Metropolis, Giusta deposited there yesterday 3000 dollars to my credit; for which I gave him my note upon interest at 5 per Cent a year; payable one year from the date— I took a draft of 350 dollars on the Girard Bank, Philadelphia— Mrs James’s Son came and paid her Quarter’s rent due yesterday— Giusta, and his wife came, and Mr and Mrs Frye to take leave— We dismissed Rachel our Cook, who is going to be married, and William a black man Servant. Mrs Goods remains to take care of the house and Brannan who cultivates the garden, and lives in the house there— We dined at two O’Clock, and in Joseph Abbot’s hack came to the Railway Cars—My wife—My daughter in Law, Mary-Catherine; her two infant daughters, Mary Louisa and Georgiana Frances, Mrs Wilson, Catherine Goods, and a light coloured serving man named—Grimes—leaving Wilson to come on with the Horses. The Rail-way Cars started five minutes before 4 O’Clock and at half-past six we were at the starting point at Baltimore— The locomotive engine, was then detached from the Cars, and horses were tackled to them in its place; which brought us to the depot in the City— Thence we walked to Barnum’s Hotel, where we obtained lodgings for the Night— There were several members of the Senate and of the House; fellow travellers with us in the Cars, but too distant from us for conversation—A. Robbins, W. R. King of Alabama, and Walker of Mississippi, Senators, F. Pierce, Cave Johnson, R. M. Johnson and Shields of the House— Mrs Adams sent word to Mr and Mrs Newman, that we were at Barnum’s; with an invitation to them to come and see us—but Mrs Newman sent word that Mr Newman was gone out and that if he should return before too late in the Evening they would come— Mr Barnum himself was our only evening visitor— He himself now resides in the Country in the vicinity of the City— The day was very warm, but the ride pleasant—
7— V— Thursday— From Baltimore to Philadelphia.

At 6. O’Clock this morning we embarked in the Steamer George Washington, CaptainMy Umbrella was left behind at Barnum’s, and before we had gone half way down the Street Grimes was sent back for it— Our baggage was under his charge, and had been laden with other baggage in a horse waggon at the Hotel— The Steamer was crowded with upwards of 400 passengers— When Grimes came down to the wharf the baggage waggon was partly unladen, and deposited in the large common waggon Car in the Steamer. Wilson with the Horses was on the wharf but the boat was so crowded that he could not get with them on board— The day was one of the hottest of the Summer, with a clear bright burning Sun—it was past 11. when we reached Frenchtown— The cars there were delayed more than half an hour, in stowing the excessive quantity of baggage— At half past twelve we reached Newcastle and embarked in the Steamer Ohio Captain Jeffreys It was near four when we reached Chesnut Street wharf at Philadelphia; and on overhauling the baggage my trunk was missing— We drove first to the Marshall Hotel in Chesnut Street— All full— Mrrecommended to us a Mrs Drummond’s and went there with us— She had not sufficient accommodations— I went to the Mansion House, to Congress Hall; to the Tremont House, to the United States Hotel— Not a square inch of space for lodgings any where— Mrrecommended me to Mrs Bradley’s two doors above the United States Hotel, and we finally found two comfortable Bed chambers there— I wrote to Mr Barnum at Baltimore, to have search made for my trunk— There were several fellow boarders at Mrs Bradley’s, but I had not time to learn their names— We met them at the tea-table— I went to Mr Nicholas Biddle’s, and after sitting some time with him He walked with me to Mrs Bradley’s and saw Mrs Adams— Among the passengers in the Boats from Baltimore were Mr and Mrs Leonard Jarvis—Franklin Pierce. And Silas Wright who had gone back to Baltimore in search of his lost Trunk and had found it.
8. IV:45 Friday

My wife, with Mary, her two children, Mrs Wilson Catherine Goods and Grimes proceeded on their Journey homeward in the Steamer Trenton, which departed from Chesnut Street wharf, at 6. O’Clock, this morning— I saw them go, and asked the attention to them of Leonard Jarvis who was also in the boat Mr Robbins Senator from Rhode-Island, R. M. and Cave Johnson and Shields of Tennessee were likewise there; and Jenifer was going in the Ohio-for-Baltimore— I returned to Mrs Bradleys and thence came before breakfast to Mr Biddle’s After breakfast I had visits from Benjamin Lundy and Lewis C. Gunn, Editor of the Times and Independent-Press— They wished me to address the Anti-Slavery Societies which I declined. I went with Mr Biddle to the Bank; left the gold there, which I had brought from Washington, and most narrowly escaped from losing with my trunk—and I took a draft for 700 dollars on the Office of discount and deposit at Boston; payable to my order, and thus not liable to be lost in the conveyance. And this incident, the loss of my trunk has painfully proved how excessively dangerous it is to carry any thing of much value with you in this Railway and Steamboat travelling.— I settled my Bill, at Mrs Bradley’s, and returned to Mr Biddle’s where I was writing and reading till 3. O’Clock— Visit from Mr John Connell, who invited me to dine with him, but I declined. He had engaged Mr Caleb Cushing and two other friends— I went to the wharf and waited near an hour for the return of the Steamer Ohio from New castle, but she came not— Came back and dined with Mr Biddle— Second visit from Benjamin Lundy, with Edwin P. Atlee— Ride with Mr Biddle—first to the wharf Ohio there Saw Captain Jeffreys— No tidings of my trunk— Nor of Wilson and the horses—but there was a derelict Portmanteau Trunk with a Camblet Cloak strap’d over it like mine—which may possibly have been taken in its place— Ride to Laurel Hill,—Once a magnificent Country seat of Mr. Simms then a Roman Catholic Seminary, Now a Cemetery in imitation of Mount Auburn. After our return, visit from W. B. Reed.
9. V:30. Saturday

The four persons first named came this morning as Committees— 1. Of the Pennsylvania Society for promoting the abolition of Slavery. 2. Of the Philadelphia Anti-Slavery Society with votes of thanks to me and to the other members of Congress who at the late Session of Congress opposed the influence of the Slavery predominant party in that body. I desired them to return my thanks to the respective Societies for the honour they had done me by these Resolutions and to assure them of the grateful sentiments with which I received them— One of the Resolutions contained also an invitation of attendance at a public meeting, which I declined; and I gave them a full and candid exposition of my own principles and views with regard to the Institution of Domestic Slavery differing from theirs under a sense of the compact and compromise in the Constitution of the United States— I declined attendance at any public meeting of the Societies, and said I believed the cause itself would be more benefited by such Service as I could render to it, in the discharge of my duty in Congress than by giving notoriety to any action on my part in support of the Societies, or in connection with them— They acquiesced in these determinations, and declared themselves well satisfied with the result of this interview— Charles J. Ingersoll and Commodore Biddle left cards of visitation for me— I kept house till Mr Biddle came home to dinner; then went with him to Chesnut Street wharf, where the Ohio Steamer was lying: and Captain Jeffreys relieved me with the tidings, that Wilson and the Horses, and my missing trunk, had all come up with him— We returned to Mr Biddle’s, where we found Wilson, and the Trunk— I charged him to go on with the Horses, Monday Morning, intending the next day to follow him— I then rode out with Mr Biddle to his Country Seat on the Banks of the Delaware—Andalusia; 14 miles from the City, on the road through Frankford towards Bristol— Mrs Biddle and her three young daughters Meta, Adele andwere there, and the family Meeting, was as of beings in Paradise before the fall— The day was of intense Summer heat
10. V:30. Sunday— Return to Philadelphia.

Immediately after rising this morning I bathed, and swam about five minutes in the Delaware river fronting the House— The tide was out and the water low— There was a bathing House, but no water under it— After breakfast I walked with Mr Biddle round his grounds— He has recently enlarged the House, and given it a front looking upon the river, with a Piazza, supported by columns, a fac-simile of the Temple of Theseus— There is a front parlour and drawing room opening to each other, and a dining room at the back of them on the ground floor, and the floor above is laid out in eight or ten bed-chambers, two fronting on the river, and with a common entry to them all— A choice library of English, French and classical Literature is in the Parlour on the ground floor— The grounds round the house, are chiefly covered with a forest of Oak and Ash, and Beech and Pine and other antient trees; but at about a furlong’s distance from the house—two green-houses each 200 feet long have just been built, for the cultivation of grapes, and are already stocked with three rows of Vines—Black-Hamburg, Muscat-Lunel Sweet waters and many others— There is also a small vineyard of one or two acres in the open air— The remnant of an antient dwelling house is yet to be removed—and other fruits than the grape are yet to be raised and cultivated. There is a Summer house, and billiard room close upon the border of the river; but no fruit or flower garden yet inviting observation— After the morning excursion and visiting the children at dump?-castle, I amused the leisure of the day with Woodfall’s Junius, and the volume identifying Junius with Sir Philip Francis, till dinner time; after which I returned with Mr Biddle to Philadelphia— At the Inn at Frankford where we stop’d to water the Horse there was a notice posted up inviting the inhabitants of Frankford to a public meeting, for the purpose of forming a philosophical Society, and requesting a general attendance— It was dated 8. April 1836. and gave rise to reflections between Mr Biddle and me.
11. VI. Monday.
With praise and prayer to God, and a solemn sense of my earthly condition, and hopes of a better world, I enter upon the seventieth year of my pilgrimage.

Benjamin Lundy came this morning and in a conversation of about two hours, made me acquainted with his principles, prospects and purposes relating to Slavery. He was heretofore the Editor of the Genius of Universal emancipation; and has now the intention of commencing the publication of a Newspaper devoted like that to the extinguishment of Slavery— A cause which within the last two or three years has fallen into great discouragement— He solicited assistance from me, for the matter of his proposed publication but I thought best not to give him any expectation of it— Mr John Vaughan called, and invited me to breakfast with him to-morrow morning with Captain La Place, Commander of the French Frigate L’Artemise, now lying in the Harbour of New-York— But I had made my arrangements to go in the six O’Clock morning boat, and was obliged to decline Mr Vaughan’s invitation— Judge Hopkinson with Commodore Biddle, and Mr Huntt Dr Huntt’s brother successively came, and engaged me in conversation till I was called to dinner so that I was unable to pay the visit I had intended to Charles J. Ingersoll. Mrs Biddle came in from the Country before dinner with her daughter Meta— After dinner Mr William B. Reed came in, but I had no time to converse with him— Benjamin Lundy came at six, and I walked with him to the house of his friend James Mott, N. 136. North Ninth Street, where the was a large tea and evening party of men and women, all of the Society of Friends— I had free conversation with them till between ten and 11. O’Clock, upon Slavery—the abolition of Slavery and other topics—of all which the only exceptionable part was the undue proportion of the talking assumed by me, and the indiscretion and vanity in which I indulged myself— Lucretia Mott the mistress of the House wife of James Mott is a native of the Island of Nantucket and had heard of my visit there last September— She is sensible and lively and an abolitionist of the most intrepid School— Benjamin Lundy and another Friend came home with me to Mr Biddle’s and Lundy came in and conversed with me nearly another hour— Mr Biddle the came in; and I completed the day with him till Midnight.
12. V. Tuesday.— From Philadelphia to New-York—and into the Long-Island Sound.

Mr Biddle walked with me to the Chesnut Street wharf, where I embarked in the Steamer New-Philadelphia, in which there were from three to four hundred passengers, with not one of whom I was personally acquainted. We found there Benjamin Lundy of whom and of my friend Biddle I soon took leave— At five minutes after six we departed from the wharf and after an solitary navigation of nearly three hours I landed and took the Rail-road car at Bordentown— I marked the Castle of Andalusia, as we glided by it upon the river— In the Car from Bordentown to Amboy, there was a man apparently from the Eastern shore of Maryland with three women who called him uncle— Middle-aged women; but they reminded me of the weird Sisters, and I could not muster courage to speak to either of them There were two other men in the same compartment of the Car, but silence was the order of the day till shortly before noon when we reached Amboy, and entered once more a Steamer. Here I found Wilson with my horses— He came down the Delaware yesterday morning; but from Bordentown to Amboy came on with the horses themselves and not upon the Rail-way Cars. With them he could not keep pace—and was therefore obliged to wait at Amboy for this days boat— We landed at New-York soon after two-O’Clock, and after finding the Steamer Boston high up the North river at the foot of Chambers-Street and that she was to depart at five for Providence, I strolled into the City and viewed the Astor House now finished, and the quarter of the city destroyed last Winter by fire, one half of which is nearly rebuilt I returned to the Boat— One of the Sons of George Sullivan accosted me in the Street, and said his father wished to know where I lodged to call upon me— I told him it would give me great pleasure to see him, but that I was proceeding immediately home without stopping at New-York at all— On my return to the boat after a shower I found that Wilson could not get the horses taken on board and must wait to go on to-morrow. Mr and Mrs Edward Brooks with their little daughter Ann Gorham, Mr Jonathan Amory, Son of my deceased Classmate, and his Son of the same name a lad of eight or nine years of age, and his father in Law, Dr Austin, a West Indian from Barbadoes, Mr Caleb Cushing, and Mr Horatio Greenough the Sculptor, are some of our fellow passengers.
13. V. Wednesday— From Watch-Hill Light to Providence, Boston— Quincy—

The Steamer Boston, Captain Toucey is the smallest of those on the line between New-York and Providence— There was through the Night a fresh eastern breeze, but the Sea was smooth, and I slept till near five O’Clock, when the Ocean swell of the Eastern side of Fisher’s Island awoke me, and on rising I found the boat, with the Watch hill light in view a fresh Eastern wind calling for a cloak and a thickening fog— Most of the Passengers Sea-sick— With some delay and repeatedly laying to, we came round Point Judith between 7 and 8 O’Clock—landed several passengers and took in others at Newport about 9. Among those who landed was Mr Jonathan Amory and Dr Austin, his father in Law, and his family— I saw upon the wharf Coll. J. T. Apthorp and marked the contrast of 25 and 70.— We landed at Providence just before Noon, and immediately entered the Railway Cars for Boston— There we alighted at twenty minutes past two; traveling steadily at the rate of twenty-four miles an hour; or two minutes and a half to a mile— The distance marked by mile-posts is forty-one miles, and they stop the train twice at 11 and 13 miles distance, about five minutes distance each time. I marked the last run of 14 miles by my watch, and they were traversed in 35 minutes— I had my baggage taken immediately taken to the Quincy Stage-house in Elm-Street; went to my Son Charles’s House, and saw his three children, Louisa-Catherine, John Quincy and Charles Francis all well, with Mrs Field, and Catherine— My Son Charles and his wife are absent upon an excursion to Niagara Falls— I returned at half-past four O’Clock to Elm Street, and with Gillett’s Stage came out to Quincy, and alighted before six O’Clock at my own house; finding all my family safe and well, and my Cousin Louisa-Catherine Smith with them. The two children were confined to the chamber with colds taken since their arrival here, and the sudden change from Midsummer heat to Northeastern cold, with fire in the dining room— The family reached home all safe on Saturday.— I visited my Garden, and Nursery before dark, and found them in tolerable order— My seedling trees in poor condition
14. VI. Thursday.

I received on my arrival last Evening a letter of notification from President Quincy that there would be to morrow a meeting of the Committee of the Overseers of the University for the examination of the Library—and this morning I received a Letter from Samuel T. Armstrong, Mayor of Boston expressing a wish to see and consult with me concerning an Oration to be delivered before the municipal Government of the City in honour of James Madison— I answered Mr Armstrong that I shall be happy to see him at any time according to his own convenience, after to-morrow when I should be a Cambridge— My wife and Louisa C Smith went to Boston to see Charles’s children, and returned home before dinner— I visited again my garden and Nursery, and found my seedling trees in very unpromising condition— Not a single peach on any one tree— Not one Apricot or Nectarine. Not a cherry—Plums only upon one tree in the Garden— Two of the finest young Apple-trees which I had planted, procured in 1830 at Medford, are completely girdled about a foot above ground, by field mice under the Snow, in the winter. They are in full leaf now, flourishing apparently as if nothing had happened to them; but Price Greenleaf says they will never bear another leaf after this year— The maple seedlings of which I brought the seeds from Philadelphia last year are looking well, the most thrifty of them being however strip’d of its growth of leaves of this Season by the beetle bug— Of my last year’s plantation of Seeds and Stones a very small part have come up, and the Season has been very unfavourable to their growth— My plantation dream is over, and I have learnt nothing, but the disappointments in which all such dreams must terminate—Josiah Adams junr was here, and told me that he had not yet finished the work of building and repairs at Mount Wollaston, for which he contracted with me last Autumn— I began reading with my Grand-daughter Mary-Louisa, the Book of Isaiah— We had Evening visits from E. Price Greenleaf, and from Mr Beale and his daughter Ann— John Wilson arrived with his Horses from New-York at four O’Clock this afternoon— He came in the Steamer Massachusetts, which left New-York at 6. O’Clock yesterday morning, and arrived at Providence at ten last Evening, with a boisterous passage round Point Judith.
15. V. Friday
Cambridge— Boston— Quincy.

At seven this morning I left home in a hired Carryall with one horse and Wilson as driver. Went through Roxbury—to Cambridge. At 9 O’Clock the Committee for the examination of the Library met in the Hall where it is kept. My Classmate Dr Thaddeus Mason Harris was the Chairman of the Committee and told me this was the 46th. year of his attendance upon this Service— The Committee consists of 20 persons, not all necessarily members of the board of Overseers, by whom they are chosen— There were present Dr Harris, Dr Thomas Gray, Mr W. Jenks, Dr F. Parkman, D. Sharp S. K. Lothrop, S. P. P. Fay, Asahel Stearns and Mr Nahum Mitchell, Revd. W. Newell, J. A. Albro—and several others unknown to me— I examined personally with Mr Sibley three of the Alcoves, and nearly the whole of the philosophical Apparatus shewn us by Professor Farrar— The Chairman of the Committee was authorized to prepare a report to the board of Overseers at the next winter Session of the Legislature, and to incorporate therein the report received from the LibrarianHarris the Son of my old Classmate— A Subcommittee of three was appointed, Dr Jenks Dr Parkman and myself, of which I was requested to act as Chairman; to report upon the deficiencies of the Library— At one O’Clock we dined in the dining Hall of the Corporation after a slight review of the Library of the Law School, where we saw Mr. Simon Greenleaf the Royall Professor of Law— After this I went with President Quincy to his house, and saw Mrs Quincy; and her daughter Elizabeth Susan Quincy— She read to me two Letters which she had received from Miss Edgeworth; in one of which my father was mentioned in a manner which deeply affected me— Miss Quincy had also a copy of my Letter to the Freshman Baker, with half the paraphrase of the ode to Aristius Fuscus.— Returning from Cambridge I came through Boston, and called upon the Mayor Mr Armstrong. He asked my opinion with regard to an Oration in honour of Mr Madison, and whether I would undertake it— Of the expediency I said the City Government must themselves judge—but if they thought proper to call upon me I would readily undertake it— He said he would propose it to the City Government next week; and would see me again concerning it— I came home about 7. O’Clock Mr and Mrs Lunt paid us an evening visit.
16. VI. Saturday.

My daily occupations here are altogether different from those which consume the time at Washington— They are here to a considerable extent voluntary, and in some former years I have allowed too much of the day to be wasted in frivolous employment— To the Garden and Nursery I must devote fewer hours than heretofore; satisfied as I am that I can discover nothing new in the Science of plantation, and that I have seedlings enough, of which to observe the growth and decay for the remainder of my days. I visited my garden and Nursery, morning and afternoon, and pruned some of my trees; observing the rapid growth of my seedling elms, and the slow growth of all but the English Oaks; and especially that of all transplanted trees. Morning visit from Mr Whitney our Senior pastor, and in the afternoon from Mr Armstrong the Mayor of Boston, with Mrs Armstrong, and from President Quincy, and his Son, Josiah, who is also President; that is of the Common Council of the City— Mr. Armstrong gave me a pamphlet upon the introduction of soft water into Boston; and I gave him copies of my Oration upon the 4th. of July 1831. at Quincy and of my Eulogy upon James Monroe— Mr Armstrong said he had mentioned to several persons the proposal for an Oration in honour of James Madison, which all had approved— That he would propose it to the board of Aldermen next Monday, and that there would be a Meeting of the Common Council, the next or succeeding day— He supposed a Committee would be appointed to come in person, and invite me to deliver this Oration; which I think it advisable to await— I brought up these minutes of my diary, and read a few pages of the History of Texas— In the evening, I went to Mrs Ann Adams’s, and there found with her, Mrs Stebbins her Sister—Elizabeth C her daughter, and Joseph H. the Midshipman her Son, just before returned home from a visit to Portland.— Mr and Mrs Edward Miller, with their daughter, Miss Mansfield, and Miss Merritt came in while I was there— I came home with the Evening Bell— Mrs and Miss Miller had visited our Ladies this morning. Isaac Hull Adams, has resigned as a Cadet at West Point, and my niece Abigail Louisa Smith Johnson, daughter of my brother Charles and wife of Alexander B. Johnson of Utica, New-York is dead, at the age of 38, leaving a family of nine children.
17. V:30. Sunday.

Heard Mr Lunt morning and afternoon— First from 1. Corinthians 15.46. “Howbeit, that was not first which is spiritual, but that which is natural; and afterwards that which is spiritual.”— This 15th. chapter of the first Epistle to the Corinthians is a deep study for a sincere and reflecting Christian— St. Paul answers the enquirer how the dead shall be raised, and with what bodies they shall come, first by calling him a fool—why does he call him a fool? Was it not because he could not answer it? He then however attempts to answer it by marking the distinction between matter and Spirit, and by the analogy of vegetation from the seed— But if matter and Spirit are existences distinct and independent of each other what analogy can there be between them; and if the resurrection of the body is analogous to the growth of the plant from the seed, where is the seminal principle in the dead body, which shall rise incorruptible and immortal? The analogy between vegetable and animal nature is in the power of reproduction, and not of regeneration— The plant produced from the seed is not immortal; nor is it more glorious than the seed itself— It bears within itself the seed of reproduction; and thus perpetuates the race, while the individual is perishable— Mr Lunt’s text says that the spiritual comes after the natural—and this starts another perplexing question which perhaps it were equally foolish to ask, since inspiration itself has not thought proper to answer it— Mr Lunt’s afternoon discourse was from Matthew 26:11. [“]For ye have the poor always with you; but me ye have not always.”— Mr Degrand came out from Boston and dined with us. And Elizabeth C Adams and her brother Joseph were here towards Evening.— I read the fourth Sermon of the eighth volume of Saurin, upon the ministry of the Angels— The text is from Hebrews 1.7. which is a quotation from Psalm 104.4. Saurin gives the text, he makes the winds his angels, and that flame of fire his ministers— The English Translation has it who maketh his angels Spirits, and his ministers a flame of fire— Cherubim therefore are only personifications of Wind; and Seraphim of fire—and these are the Angels or Ministers of God— Saurin says there are two Classes of Spirits—Angels and Demons, and two corresponding classes of men, all belonging to the one or the other.— I went this Evening to visit Mr Thomas Greenleaf, but he was not at home.
18. VI. Monday

Alpheus Spear came this morning and settled with me for the rent of the Mount Wollaston farm to the 31st. of last March when his old lease expired— I entered upon it a discharge in full, and exchanged the copies of it with him— I resumed again the reading of the Bible with my two Grand-children— That of the Book of Isaiah with Mary Louisa, which has been three days interrupted by her indisposition—and that of the Psalms, in the Book of Common prayer, with them both—beginning at the Morning of the 12th. day where we had ceased at Washington— Wilson went to Boston, in search of his trunk which he left at Providence in charge of Captain Comstock of the Steamboat Massachusetts to be forwarded by the Railway Cars, but which has not yet come. Mr John Taliaferro, member of the House of Representatives from Fredericsburg, Virginia, had written to me, requesting a copy in my own handwriting of my address to the House on the occasion of the decease of James Madison— I began making the copy yesterday, and finished it this day; and answered Mr Taliaferro’s Letter— I collected the papers sent to me by Benjamin Lundy and which he has requested me to return. With them I put up my Report of the minority of the Committee of Manufactures made in Feby 1833. which I send for Lewis C. Gunn, Editor of the Times and Independent Press a weekly Newspaper, published at Philadelphia— Louisa C. Smith, left us this afternoon and went to Mrs Ann Adams’s— I had a visit while we were at tea from Mr John D. Williams of Boston. And I paid one in the Evening at Mr Thomas Greenleaf’s, and borrowed of him the copy I had sent him of my Speech on the distribution of Rations to send to Benjamin Lundy. My day thus slip’d away from under me, and at its close I found that I had done nothing— So it always is when I have not my allotted task before me— I find not even time for steady reading, and make scarcely any progress in the History of Texas by David B. Edward, which I brought with me from Philadelphia— My garden and Nursery afford me as yet not much amusement— The full grown trees bear neither peaches nor cherries nor plums— The seedlings of former years have scarcely any perceptible growth, and it is too late to discover the first appearance of those of the present year.
19. V:30. Tuesday

Isaac Hull Adams and his brother Joseph Harrod were here this morning— Hull has resigned his situation as a Cadet at the Military academy at West-Point, and went to Washington, and had been there several days before we left there to endeavour to obtain a re-instatement there. He did not let me know that he was there, but went to the President who gave him good words, and to the Secretary of War, who advised him not to stay at Washington, and who afterwards wrote him, that he saw no reason for re-instating him at West-Point— He was obliged to resign because he was reported for absence from his post, being then under censure, for a similar violation of the rules, for which he had been tried and convicted by a Court Martial— The second by which he had been sentenced since his admission to the Academy. Joseph H. the Midshipman manifests no disposition to return to the duties of his profession— Mr Storrs the Minister of the first congregational church in Braintree was here with Mrs Storrs— He has been for some years absent from his Parish, as a home Missionary; but he says he is to return permanently to his residence at Braintree next September— Harmon came here with a highway tax bill for the Town of Braintree— Mr E. Price Greenleaf came this afternoon, and walked with me over my garden, Nursery and Eastern Seminary, and examined most of my seedling trees— Those that have come up the present Season, do not interest me, as those of former years have done— I wish they would not interest me at all, for then I should waste no more time upon them. I found a third of my apple-trees from Medford, which I have been six years cherishing in my Garden, girdled by the mice—
20. V:30 Wednesday

And how my way of life is changed! E. Price Greenleaf came this morning and I walked with him to the Mount Wollaston farm— The Orchard, planted in November 1830. makes but a poor appearance— The border of forest trees round it, Oaks, Chesnuts and Shag-bark Walnuts is far more promising— The nuts and acorns were all planted by myself or in my presence— Nothing has been done to favour their growth or for their preservation since, and from those nuts and acorns there are not less than six hundred trees growing, with roots which have been six years piercing and taking hold of the soil— Most of them however have year after year died down to the surface of the earth in winter, and then thrown up several shoots; without forming one durable stem— The fourth side of the border, where none of my former seedlings had survived was replanted last Autumn, with Shag-bark nuts and Ash seeds, many of which have come up— A number of Elms, transplanted from my Nursery have taken root, and put forth leaves; but every one of the English Oaks, has died down to the ground— Three or four of them have thrown out new shoots which may yet live.— The greater part of the Baldwin Apple-trees are dying, or make no progress— After viewing the whole border round, I returned home to dinner— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us— Mr Everett and Mr Hallett came out from Boston after dinner and took tea here— We had some conversation upon political affairs, but there is a flat calm in the political world at this moment— Louisa C Smith, and Mrs Mary Dawes were here after tea, and Mr Edward Miller in the Evening— And thus the whole day was absorbed by my visit to Mount Wollaston, and by company leaving me scarcely an hour for reading or writing— I however heard the children read, and after nine in the Evening wrote the Journal of yesterday— My library presents me perpetual temptations to desultory reading, a few pages in one book, and a few pages in another, of which memory can now retain little or nothing. I have taken for the moment to the Journal of the first Congress of our Revolution in September 1774. where I find matter for meditation.
21. IV:30. Thursday.
Planted one ripe garden will? Strawberry in Pot N.fresh filled

A man by the name of Le Brun came with a Letter of introduction dated at Portland, Maine, from F. O. J. Smith, the member of the House of Representatives of the U.S. from that District— The Letter spelt his name Le Bron, and he told me he was so called because the Americans could not pronounce his name with the French sound of Le Brun. But his object was to tell me that he had invented a composition material for building dwelling Houses, incomparably superior to Wood, Brick or Stone; much cheaper, and durable to the end of Time— And that he had petitioned Congress at their last Session, to purchase of him the secret of this invention— That his Petition, Mr Smith told him had been referred to a Committee of which I was chairman, and which had not reported— I told him this was a mistake— That I had never heard of his Petition, and that if referred to a Committee it might have been to the one of which Mr Gorham Parks was Chairman— But that Congress never purchased inventions, and his best way to make his invention profitable to himself would be to take out a patent for it. This he said he would not do, but he argued the duty of Congress to purchase an invention of such unparalleled usefulness— I did not reply to his argument, but assured him that it would not avail in Congress, and he took his leave— Josiah Adams junr. came for a supply of money towards finishing the new house at Mount Wollaston, and upon a project of alteration to this mansion house. My wife, with Mary, the two Children and Elizabeth C. Adams went into Boston this afternoon, and returned just before the Evening bell— Wilson at last received his trunk which he had left at Providence and feared was lost. Isaac H. Adams the ex-Cadet came to solicit my interposition to obtain his reinstatement there, which I peremptorily refused— Without positive vice, he is irredeemably unfit for West-Point, the army or the world. I told him so, and he took it with indifference perfectly cool— I wrote a couple of pages this day; and read Alexander H. Everett’s Bunker Hill Address, delivered on the last Anniversary of that Battle— An eloquent production.
22. IV:15. Friday.

Joseph H. Adams was here this morning— I visited my eastern Seminary and sheltered about 30 seedling Apple-trees and ten Pear trees, and one Plum from the scorching heat of the Sun— The seedlings of last year there have almost all survived the winter, and now need no shelter— This afternoon Aldermen Greele and Hunting and the members of the common Council of the City of Boston came out as a Committee and invited me in the name of the City Government to deliver before them an Eulogy upon the life and character of the late James Madison— Mr Greele delivered to me a Letter of Introduction from the Mayor Samuel T. Armstrong— I accepted this invitation with an aching heart; under a deep feeling of my incompetency to do the subject Justice; and a consciousness of the hours of anguish which opens before me till the work shall have been performed— The day is hereafter to be fixed—the last week in August, or first in September— I am destitute of almost all the indispensable materials— Mercy and Susan Tufts were here as visitors from Weymouth; and in the Evening Mr Beale and Dr Woodward— The Midshipman took Fanny to dine at his Mothers and my wife and Mary with Louisa went there to tea— I walked there after them, but met the carriage returning with them home— I found Mr Edward Miller with his daughter Hannah there— I came home with the Evening Bell— Wrote two pages of preliminary matter and wasted several hours, in looking up in the British State Trials, the Trial of John Peter Zenger at New-York for a libel in 1735—and then in a search to ascertain all the members of the first Congress under the present Constitution of the Union— I found in the town Library a Copy of the Edition of the Federalist published in 1818. with the Letters of Pacificus and of Helvidius as an Appendix—
23. IV:30. Saturday

Morning hour occupied inspecting my seedlings of the present year— After the first Season the growth of most of them is so imperceptible that I scarcely notice them, and now the ninth year since I began my plantations they still bear no fruit— There are this year neither peaches plums nor cherries but I have about thirty seedling Apple trees along the Eastern end of the House.

Mr Brooks of Medford, with his Son Edward, and my Son Charles came out from Boston, this morning but returned before dinner Charles with his wife got home from their excursion of six weeks to the falls of Niagara, and to Quebec and Montreal in Canada— His wife has returned unwell, and she could not come out with him, but they are both much delighted with their tour— After dinner, my wife and Mary went into Boston to see them and returned with the Evening Bell. While they were gone, Mr and Mrs Felt came out from Boston where they now reside, to visit us— I had not seen them since September 1829. and did not know them— Mrs Felt especially has very much changed. Towards Evening Mrs Angier was here, with Mr Buttrick, and Elizabeth C. Adams. Mrs Angier came from Medford this afternoon— Visitors are not the only occasions of interruption to my occupations which I experience every hour of the day. I went again in search of the trial of John Peter Zenger for a libel in 1738. and found an account of it in the continuation of Smith’s History of New-York presented to me two years ago, part of the five volumes of transactions of the New-York Historical Society— I think this was the first occasion of a trial for libel, in which the principle was maintained as a point of defence that the truth could be shewn in justification of the libellous charge— I fell also in search of facts relating to the life of Mr Madison, upon the four Volumes of Jefferson’s writings, which led me wide astray from that subject into a multitude of others— My present special pursuit is the graduation of the History of our federal Union from the first Congress of 1774, to the present Constitution of the United States— A progress which I wish to trace as illustrative of the life and character of James Madison
24. IV:45. Sunday

Heard Mr Peter Whitney the Senior Pastor, from Exodus 20.5—[“]For I, the Lord thy God am a jealous God, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me; 6. and shewing mercy unto thousands of them that love me, and keep my commandments.”— There was some explanation of the sense, in which God is said to be a jealous God; and also of the visitation of the iniquity of the fathers upon the children—an opposite promise being contained the book of Ezekiel— Mr Whitney’s voice was much enfeebled, and his eye-sight has much failed. There was after the morning service a collection made for the Library of the Sunday School— Joseph H. Adams dined with us. After dinner Mr Lunt preached from John 1:14. “And the word was made flesh, and dwelt among us”— The word is the Logos, and in the Latin language, the verb—Is not the word, the “I am” the eternal being—without beginning of days or end of years— I could not avoid writing, yet wrote to little purpose. Mrs Angier and Mr Buttrick returned after calling here this afternoon to Medford— In the Evening with Mr E. P. Greenleaf I paid a visit to Mr Lunt— Mrs Lunt’s mother Mrs Hedge was there— After returning home, I read the 5th. Sermon of the 8th. Volume of Saurin, upon Charity— His text is from Galatians 6.10. As we have therefore opportunity let us do good unto all men, especially unto them who are of the household of faith— The french translation has it to the domestics of Faith which somewhat modifies the thought— Instead of as we have opportunity; the French version is, while we have the Time for it— Saurin according to his custom analyses his text and comments upon every part of it— On the Time that must be seized to do good, on the duty of doing good to all men—and on the special duty as applied to the domestics of Faith—and he explains the seeming conflict of the text with itself— I wrote to Harriet Welsh at Fishkill landing, and enclosed a Letter of Introduction for her to Daniel Brent, Consul of the U.S at Paris— She is going to Europe with Mr and Mrs Nash.
25. IV:30. Monday.
